title: Agents and avatars: A new era of computational social science

Is doing out at HP and that's why I'm suggesting that we were looking at a new era of computational social science that focuses on the ways in which local interactions at the micro level among individuals generate macrosocial or population level patterns.
And there are three basic areas where I see this work beginning to unfold.
The first is the use of agent based models, which which model interactions.
Amongst independently programmed agents, so each so it's instead of having a model of a population as you would for instance in systems dynamics, you have a population of models.
Each model is its own program.

A second area online controlled cross cultural experiments, of which I'm going to show you a couple of examples and then finally digital traces of online interactions.

In this experiment funded by DARPA, we studied conflict management, the conventional strategy in conflict management is to promote tolerance between the groups.
It doesn't work, and we used an agent model to show.
Why it doesn't work?

Which is that the conflict escalates and as it escalates you get social control in each of those groups, which makes it very difficult for people to have tolerance, because if you're tolerant of an outgroup in the middle of a fierce ethnic conflict, you don't have to worry about the other group.
You have to worry about the people in your own group who are going to come down on you.
That's our theory.
